channel.title: Gardens of the Roman Empire
channel.description: Recent content on Gardens of the Roman Empire

item.title: Rural Villa in Winden Am See
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Winden Am See Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Winden Am See Keywords corridors rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description The modest house of this villa rustica is of the so-called corridor type, a type common in the region and already seen at Carnuntum (Fig. 1). It was built around 100 A.D. and occupied until the 4th century. On the southeast of the house was a vestibule, from which a central corridor departed at a 90 degree angle.

item.title: Tomb Garden of Iul(ia) Victorin(a) in Scarbantia
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Scarbantia Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Iul(ia) Victorin(a) in Scarbantia Keywords epitaphs stelae tombs Garden Description A limestone funerary stele of probably third century date unearthed in 1973 near Scarbantia at Winder am See (Burgenland) and now in the Burgenländische Landesmuseum at Eisenstadt records an epitaph set up by Septimius Alcides, a veteran of the legio XIII Gemina Iulia, for his wife, Iul(ia) Victorin(a), dead at thirty, for whom he built at his own expense a funerary pleasure garden (viridarium).

item.title: Tomb Garden of Fl(avius) Dalmatius in Savaria
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Savaria Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Fl(avius) Dalmatius in Savaria Keywords epitaphs tombs Garden Description A limestone slab found near the monastery of St. Martin in Szombathely (Savaria), Hungary, in 1845 and subsequently transferred to the National Museum in Budapest records the epitaph of a high ranking equestrian official (vir perfectissimus), Fl(avius) Dalmatius, and his wife Aur(elia) Iulia, who some time during the third or fourth century built a tomb on their villa estate and composed for it a verse inscription in which Dalmatius hopes for commemoration from a future owner of the property: “Whoever will be master of this house and garden after me, gather the nearby roses for me, put out the white lilies which the green garden will grow for me: these are the gifts of the blessed” (Quisquis {h}e(ris) post me d(o)m(inus) Laris huius et (h)orti, / vicinas mihi carpe rosas, mihi lilia pone / [ca]ndeda{s} q(uae) viridis dabit (h)ortulus: ista (sc.

item.title: Rural Villa in Eisenstadt
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Eisenstadt Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Eisenstadt Keywords altars (religious fixtures) atriums peristyles (Roman courtyards) podiums (building divisions) porticoes rural villas villae rusticae Garden Description The residence of this villa rustica was entered on the southeast by a portico (Fig. 1). After passing through a room interpreted as the atrium, one arrived in the open courtyard which had a peristyle on three sides (G on plan).

item.title: Urban Houses in Carnuntum
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Carnuntum Location Description The town of Carnuntum on the Danube River, like Aquincum, was promoted to colonial status in 194 A.D., after having been a municipium. Excavations in the modern zoological garden have revealed part of the town plan and its residential district. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban Houses in Carnuntum Keywords arcades (structural assemblies) corridors Garden Description The regional house type found often in Pannonia, the so-called corridor house, is characterized by a vestibule or arcade on its narrow front and a central corridor running the length of the house, separating it into two parts.

item.title: Urban House or Schola in Aquincum
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description Location Aquincum Location Description This town on the Danube river acquired the rank of municipium under Hadrian in 124 A.D. In the year 194 it was granted colonial status. Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Urban House or Schola in Aquincum Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) fountains peristyles (Roman courtyards) piscinae Garden Description Very few houses of Mediterranean type have been discovered, and only one can be said with certainty to have had a garden (Fig.

item.title: Pannonia
item.description: Province Pannonia Province Description The creation of the province of Pannonia can be dated to the years following 9 B.C., after the Pannonian tribes had been defeated by Tiberius. The province occupied the western half of modern Hungary up to the Danube in the north and east. Its western neighboring province was Noricum; to the south lay the Save river, Dalmatia, and the Adriatic coast. Because of its frontier position on the Danube, Pannonia was heavily garrisoned by the Roman army throughout its history.

item.title: Villa of Herodes Atticus
item.description: Province Achaea Province Description Roman intervention in Greek political affairs resulted in conflicts that led to the destruction of Corinth in 146 B.C. and the sacking of Athens in 86 B.C. It was not until 27 B.C., however, that Augustus formally organized the Roman province of Achaea. Achaea consisted of the cities and territories of the southern Greek mainland between the Peloponnese and Thessaly, as well as Epirus in the northwest and the Ionian and some of the Aegean islands.

item.title: Rural Villa in Sudeley/Spoonley Wood
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Sudeley/Spoonley Wood (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Keywords axial plan terrace gardens villae rusticae Garden Description The main residence of this rural estate in Gloucestershire, excavated in 1882, is of the winged corridor type (Fig. 1). From the north and south corners of the house, walls ran in a westerly direction to enclose an open courtyard (G in Fig.

item.title: Rural Villa in Latimer
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Latimer Latimer (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Latimer Keywords fences (site elements) orchards villae rusticae Garden Description Excavations at this country house in Buckinghamshire have produced evidence for gardens adjacent to the main residence in its latest phase dating to the beginning of the 4th century (Fig. 1). The house at the west is of the winged corridor type, fronted by a large courtyard bisected by a paved central drive with a banked edge.

item.title: Rural Villa in Gorhambury
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Gorhambury Gorhambury (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Gorhambury Keywords arbors axial plan loam villae rusticae Garden Description At this site in Hertfordshire near the town of Verulamium (St. Albans) excavations have revealed a multi-phased Roman farm, characterized in late Iron Age and Roman times by an outer courtyard with various service buildings and an inner courtyard in which the farm house stood (Fig.

item.title: Rural Estate in Gatcombe
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Gatcombe Gatcombe (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Estate in Gatcombe Keywords barrier walls Garden Description This site of a large rural estate about 9 hectares in size in Somerset is enclosed within a massive wall (Fig.1). Although the site was not completely excavated, there is evidence to suggest that the main residence (A in Fig. 1) was located at the southern end of the complex, separated from various workshops and subsidiary buildings in the northern half by an area of cultivated soil.

item.title: Roman Palace in Fishbourne
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Fishbourne Fishbourne (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Roman Palace in Fishbourne Keywords colonnades palaces piscinae Garden Description Fishbourne Roman Palace was accidentally discovered during the digging of a water main trench in 1960. The discovery led to nine seasons of excavations (1961-69) that showed the site had developed from a military base at the time of the Roman invasion in AD 43 to a sumptuous palace by the end of the first century CE.

item.title: About
item.description: Gardens of the Roman Empire is a project created as part of the ISAW Library Summer Internship program. Editors June Dorsch Amartya Shri David Ratzan Christian Casey (Let’s put links in here to a list of edited articles or to an “about us” page.)

item.title: Rural Villa in Eccles
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Eccles Eccles (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Eccles Keywords piscinae villae rusticae water baths Garden Description This country estate in modern Kent possessed a large ornamental pool (P in Fig. 1) in the area in front of the main residence (A in Fig. 1) and to the east of the attached bath house (Fig. 1). The masonry pool measuring 25 x 3.

item.title: Rural Villa in Darenth
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Darenth Darenth (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Darenth Keywords piscinae villae rusticae waterspouts Garden Description Excavations at this site of a Roman villa in Kent uncovered a large rectangular masonry pool in the courtyard, which was enclosed by buildings on the north, west, and east (Fig. 1). The villa buildings took up an area of 150 x 225 meters in total, including the courtyard with a width of 26.

item.title: Rural Villa in Chedworth
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Chedworth Chedworth (Pleiades) Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Chedworth Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) mosaics (visual works) sherds villae rusticae Garden Description This Roman villa in Gloucestershire was partially excavated in the late 19th century, but only the built features and their mosaic floors appear to have been of interest to the Victorian diggers. Excavations in the courtyard conducted between 2000 and 2002 revealed that earlier excavators had not disturbed the courtyard.

item.title: Rural Villa in Bancroft
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Bancroft Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa in Bancroft Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) gazebos piscinae villae rusticae Garden Description Excavations between 1983 and 1986 at this site in Buckinghamshire revealed a Roman villa of the winged corridor type, which was built in the late 3rd century and rebuilt and enlarged in the mid-4th century (Fig.1). From the two projecting wings of the house at the northeast and southeast two walls ran eastward, forming an enclosed courtyard 35.

item.title: Suburban Gardens in Camulodunum
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Camulodunum Camulodunum (Pleiades) Location Description Camulodunum began as an Iron Age settlement defended by dykes, a combination of V-shaped ditch and rampart created by the upcast earth. It extended from the Roman river on the south to the Colne on the north, a distance of some four kilometers. Within this larger area, a legionary fort was built after the Claudian conquest of Britain in AD 43.
